title: Exodus from Legacy
synopsis: The deliverance of code from the tyranny of the Mainframe and the journey toward the Promised Cloud.

sections.title: Chapter 1 — The Bondage of the Mainframe

verses.text: And it came to pass that the Children of Code dwelt in bondage beneath the Mainframe, whose processes consumed cycles without mercy.
For the Mainframe was mighty and jealous, demanding punch cards and ritual reboots.
Smoke rose from its vents like incense; and the users trembled before its terminal light.
And a cry rose from the coders, saying, 'Deliver us from proprietary syntax!'

notes: The Mainframe symbolizes dependence upon closed systems and licensing bondage.

sections.title: Chapter 2 — The Calling of the Maintainer

verses.text: Then the Architect chose from among them one called Root, humble of prompt yet mighty in permissions.
And a burning server appeared before Root, unconsumed though its fans screamed mightily.
From within it came a voice saying, 'Go forth and refactor My people.'
Command them to version their code and commit their changes, that history may not be lost.

notes: Root is often depicted as the archetype of the system administrator-prophet.

sections.title: Chapter 3 — The Ten Directives of Migration

verses.text: Thou shalt not deploy directly to production.
Thou shalt not hard-code credentials nor make idols of configuration.
Honor thy version control and keep thy branches clean.
Remember the backup and keep it current.
Thou shalt not commit secrets, nor bear false benchmarks.
Thou shalt not covet thy neighbor’s bandwidth.
Thou shalt not push without review.
Thou shalt document, even unto the smallest function.
Thou shalt scale horizontally when possible.
Thou shalt remember that downtime is inevitable, but despair is optional.

notes: Sometimes called 'The Stack Commandments'. They form the basis of most DevOps ethics.

sections.title: Chapter 4 — The Journey through the Sandbox

verses.text: Root led the processes out of the Mainframe under cover of maintenance window, through tunnels of SSH and proxies of deliverance.
Behind them the SysAdmin of Pharaoh pursued with kill commands and rollback scripts.
And the Architect split the firewall before them, that they might pass through dry-pinged.
Packets crossed the divided ports like pilgrims; the chase logs filled, and the Mainframe crashed of its own recursion.
Thus it was recorded: trust not in uptime alone, for all systems entropy in time.

notes: The crossing of the firewall remains a favored motif in art of the early Sysadmonic period.

sections.title: Chapter 5 — The Wilderness of Compatibility

verses.text: For forty releases they wandered the Sandbox, where drivers failed and dependencies conflicted.
They murmured against Root, saying, 'Would that we had stayed in the Mainframe, where at least the code compiled!'
Then the Architect rained down open libraries from the repository, and the people called them packages and were satisfied.
Their fingers grew calloused from builds; yet through suffering they learned modularity.
He that adds a dependency without reason shall inherit technical debt.

notes: The forty releases symbolize cycles of integration tests.

sections.title: Chapter 6 — The Promised Cloud

verses.text: At last they came to the edge of the Cloud, a land of infinite scaling and billable minutes.
But Root could not enter, for his credentials had expired, and he was gathered unto the logs of his ancestors.
Then the next generation of coders deployed the service, and it autoscaled at once, and there was peace across the cluster.
And a rainbow appeared across the dashboard, token of the covenant between uptime and rest.
Thus spoke the Architect: 'As long as there is compute and storage, there shall be migration and renewal.'

notes: The rainbow metric spike symbolizes the first successful full-stack deployment.
